p: The isolation of shikimic acid from the fruit of Illicium religiosum was primarily reported by Ekmann in 1885 [18]. The name shikimic acid was derived after the oriental plant shikimi-no-ki in Japanese. Shikimic acid is now available in more quantities through the extraction from the fruit Illicium verum (Chinese star anise). It was recently reported that Liquidambar styraciflua, more commonly known as the sweetgum tree, could be a renewable source of shikimic acid. In fact, it was shown that the sweetgum tree can yield shikimic acid in amounts comparable with that of I. verum, through the seeds of its annual fruit.
